_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: TDI contact with mositure/water, loss of plant nitrogen supply, TDI incompatibility with other chemicals present in the common vapor system.
_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Tank fill restrictions due to high specific gravity, external / mineral oil heating, carbon drums on vapor lines, separate vapor system at R-2, dessicant system on conservation vent, radar gauges
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Air monitoring, vapor line leak detection and repair (LDAR) program.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Scheduled Preventative Maintenance (PM) Inspection of TDI Storage Tank D-30-10 Vents (Express Maintenance Work Order 113090)

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: No Nitrogen Pad in ISO Container Being Loaded
_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Nitrogen Pad on ISO Container Prior to Loading to Ensure an Inert Atmosphere.  Automated Shut-Down of the Flare System.
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Permanent and Portable Fire Water Delivery Systems.  Portable Fire Extinguishers.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Quarterly Leak Detection & Repair (LDAR) Program Implemented.
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Increased Isopentane Chemical Inventory Based on Number of Rail Cars Held on Storage Tracks Simultaneously.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Routine Preventative Maintenance Inspection of the Tank Farm Vent Flare (Express Maintenance Work Order 112687)

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Loss of Inhibitor, Loss of Nitrogen Blanket, Polymerization in Marine Flare System
_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Stored in an Internal Floating Roof Tank, Nitrogen Blanketing System on Tank, Dedicated Marine Dock Line, SAAB Radar Gauge, Hermetic Gauge/Sample System, Vapor System Purges, Flared Loading
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Permanent and Portable Water Delivery Systems.  New Fire-Fighting Water Delivery Monitors Installed South of Tank P50-5.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Quarterly Fugitive Emission Leak Detection and Repair (LDAR) Program Implemented
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: VAM storage at Stolthaven Houston Inc. consolidated in 2010 into Tank P-50-5 from Tanks A-15-9, A-15-10, & P-15-41
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Routine Maintenance Inspection of Storage Tank P-50-5 Internal Floating Roof (Express Maintenance Work Order #112674)

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
PURPOSE FOR RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN RESUBMISSION / UPDATE

Stolthaven Houston Inc. is updating the facility's Risk Management Plan (RMP) in October of 2014 to revise the operating scenario for a regulated flammable substance already handled at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal, removing two processes from the RMP that no longer apply to facility operations, updating relevant site contact information, and revising various RMP data elements that have changed since the previous plan update submitted in April of 2014.  The specific changes associated with this RMP update include:

- Increasing the maximum on-site inventory for Isopentane (Process 3) based on the number of Isopentane rail cars that can be simultaneously held on Stolthaven Houston's rail car storage tracks.

- Deleting n-Pentane (previous Process 2) and Pentane Blend (previous Process 4) Intermodal Transfers from Stolthaven Houston's RMP.  These operations will no longer occur at the facility according to current customer requirements.

- Updating the RMP based on Stolthaven Houston's five-year Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) revalidation, which commenced in October of 2014.

- Minor RMP data element updates based on recent revisions to Stolthaven Houston's Emergency Action Plan (EAP) and our Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) found in the terminal's Local Training Manual (LTM), and 

- Updating the contact information for the new Terminal Manager responsible for RMP implementation at Stolthaven Houston Inc.  


§ 68.155(a):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

At Stolthaven Houston Inc. we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes related to bulk chemical storage and distribution in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning programs to protect the environment and to ensure the safety of our employees, our industrial neighbors, and the citizens of the surrounding communit

ting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets during potential emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our action plan with the community emergency response plan and the North Channel Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Stolthaven Houston Inc. is also an active member of Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA).

An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) is maintained which provides guidelines for responding to various emergencies such as fires, hazardous material spills, personal injuries, severe weather events, and property damage that may occur at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  


§ 68.155(f):  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The following is a list of current initiatives at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal to assist in preventing and/or responding to accidental chemical releases, and to help effectively manage the hazards present at the facility:

- In 2013 Stolthaven Houston hired a third-party consulting firm to perform the three-year RMP compliance audit required pursuant to 40 CFR 68, Sections §§ 68.58 and 68.79.  As a result of this third-party audit, a RMP/PSM Team was formed to address the audit findings.  This team is currently performing a comprehensive review and revision of Stolthaven Houston's RMP/PSM program to better align the program with our current work practices.  As part of this comprehensive internal review, individuals at the facility have been assigned to each of the specific RMP/PSM program elements to promote responsibility and ownership. 

- In 2014 a new role, Emergency Response Coordinator, was created and filled to the streamline the terminal's efforts in the event of a significant incident at the facility.

- Stolthaven Houston contracted with a safety consulting firm to facilitate the five-year Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) revalidation of the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  This revalidation of the facility's PHA commenced with a kick-off meeting held on October 8, 2014 during which the term

inal's overall RMP program was discussed, and the hazards associated with the Isopentane Intermodal Transfer Process (Process 2) were reviewed in detail.  Stolthaven Houston is currently reviewing the draft PHA report for Process 2; the remaining two RMP covered processes at the site will be reviewed and completed thereafter.  

- As they become available, toxic and/or flammable product storage tanks at the facility are being equipped with ball valves to replace existing gate valves as part of an ongoing safety enhancement and automation project. 

- Continuous improvement through the facility's ISO 9001: 2000 Certified Quality Management System (QMS).

- Employee Suggestion / Experienced Feedback Program.

- Regular safety meetings with Stolthaven Houston Operations Department employees and contract 
personnel working in the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.

Additional capital budget projects recently implemented or planned for 2015 to improve safety and emergency response at Stolthaven Houston Inc. include the purchase of 1,000-gallons of fire fighting foam, replacing certain fire water delivery lines in A and B-Tank Farms, adding new fire water connections on the east side of D-Tank Farm and in P-Tank Farm, replacing the terminal's spill response boat, purchasing additional fire-fighting equipment and Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) for the company's emergency response team personnel, additional surveillance cameras to be installed around the terminal's east expansion property, purchasing a new emergency response vehicle, placing sodium bentonite in A and B-Tank Farms to improve surface working conditions, and relocating the terminal's firehouse.

ies.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Stolthaven Houston Inc. has designed and implemented, including:

- A description of our facility and the substances regulated by 40 CFR Part 68 that are currently handled on-site in stationary sources above their corresponding threshold quantities (TQ)

- An overview of our accidental release prevention programs

- A five-year history of significant accidental releases from processes covered by EPA's RMP regulations

- An overview of our emergency response programs

- An overview of recent improvements at the facility implemented to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets

- Detailed information about our Risk Management Program


§ 68.155(b):  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Stolthaven Houston Inc. owns and operates an existing bulk liquids storage and distribution terminal located on the north side of the Houston Ship Channel near Channelview in eastern Harris County, Texas.  The facility currently consists of 188 large above-ground storage tanks, five truck loading/unloading racks (Racks T-3, T-4, T-5, T-6 and T-8), four rail car loading/unloading racks (Racks R-1, R-2, R-3 and R-5), one barge dock (Barge Dock-C), and a finger pier jetty equipped with two separate marine vessel berths (Ship Dock 2/3).  A biological waste water treatment plant and various air pollution control devices are also operated on-site to reduce the impact of the Stolthaven Houston Terminal on the environment.

Bulk liquid products are received into the Stolthaven Houston Inc. by various modes of transportation cargo containers that can include tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, rail tank cars, barges, and marine parcel tankers.  The received liquid products are stored on-site according to customer-specified requirements, and are subsequent

ly transferred off-site through one or more of the above-referenced transportation modes.  Stolthaven Houston Inc. also performs direct product transfers between marine vessels and rail tank cars with no intermediate tank storage.  Similarly, land-based intermodal (IMO) transfers directly between tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, and rail tank cars are also performed routinely at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  Note that Stolthaven Houston Inc. does not perform any chemical processing or chemical manufacturing operations on-site, and the company does not own nor ultimately control the disposition of the various bulk liquid products that are stored or otherwise handled at the facility.

The following chemicals presently handled at Stolthaven Houston Inc. have been identified by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as having the potential to cause significant off-site consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Regulated Toxic Substances Currently in Storage:

Toluene Diisocyanate, Mixed Isomers (CAS Number 26471-62-5)
Vinyl Acetate Monomer (CAS Number 108-05-4)

Regulated Flammable Substance Currently Handled via Intermodal Transfer:

Isopentane (CAS Number 78-78-4)


TDI and VAM currently represent the only two RMP regulated substances at Stolthaven Houston Inc. that are present on-site above their corresponding threshold quantities at all times.  Isopentane is periodically transloaded directly from rail tank cars into ISO tank containers with no intermediate storage other than that associated with the terminal's rail car storage are prior to transfer.  As a result, Isopentane is not always present at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  

Our training and accidental release prevention programs in combination with our Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) and contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the potential hazards posed to our employees, the public, and the environment through the storage and/or

transfer of the above-referenced RMP regulated chemicals.

TOLUENE DIISOCYANATE STORAGE AND TRANSFERS

Stolthaven Houston Inc. currently stores Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) in one 30,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tank (Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-30-10) and in two 15,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tanks (Low-Pressure Storage Tanks D-15-19 and D-15-22).  Tank D-30-10 has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 10,600,000-pounds (1,042,000-gallons).  Tank D-15-19 has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 5,122,000-pounds (503,600-gallons).  Tank D-15-22 has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 5,131,000-pounds (504,500-gallons).  Periodic direct transfers of TDI from marine vessels into rail tank cars is also performed at Stolthaven Houston Inc. with no intermediate product storage.  Stolthaven Houston Inc. currently has over 18-years of experience in the storage and handling of TDI. 

As part of the recent changes associated with additional TDI storage in Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-15-19, significant modifications were performed such that TDI is handled safely and efficiently in this tank, including installing a liner on the storage tank's floor and shell, installing a new line constructed of 316L stainless steel from the storage tank to the existing marine dock line in D-Manifold that is used exclusively for TDI marine-based transfers, replacing all existing gate valves on the Tank D-15-19 system with new ball valves for ease of operation, installing a new stainless-steel pump for TDI at Storage Tank D-15-19, installing new hot water external heating panels, a water tank, and associated heating panel supply/return lines for Storage Tank D-15-19 while in TDI service, insulating Tank D-15-19, installing internal eductors at the tank's recirculation line to improve product mixing, installing electric tracing and insulation on the tank's lateral line t

e Training / Local Training Manual (LTM)

- Mechanical Integrity Program

- Spill Containment

- Management of Change (MOC)

- Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

- Vapor Control Systems

- Compliance Audits

- Formal Incident Investigation

- Employee Participation Program

- Hot Work / Safe Work Permits

- Departmental / Safety Meetings

- Emergency Response Team (ERT)

- Emergency / Incident Response Contractors

The above-referenced elements of our prevention program work together to help prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we conduct business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls in place to ensure that we meet our own high standards for accident prevention.


§ 68.155(d):  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

During the preceding five years there has been one accidental release from a RMP covered process at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal which resulted in significant property damage on-site.  On the evening of August 23, 2013 nitrogen pressure was being used to unload a rail car containing TDI into one of Stolthaven Houston's on-site TDI storage tanks.  As the rail car was being unloaded, the rail switching crew on-duty coupled the terminal's locomotive to a string of rail cars, including the working TDI rail car, and began to pull the cars away from the rail rack.  As the rail car being emptied of TDI was moved, the TDI cargo hose released from the car, and the car's 1-inch valve connected to the plant nitrogen hose was sheared off.  Residual nitrogen pressure in the rail car caused approximately 4,500-gallons of TDI to be released from the sheared 1-inch valve opening on the rail car into the Rail Rack R-2 concrete containment area, with a small amount of TDI released onto an in-plant concrete road adjacent to the rack in the center of the facility.  There was no off-site release of TDI liquid.  A Stolthaven Houston

operator on duty at Rail Rack R-2 immediately closed the rail rack TDI product line valve leading to the storage tank, and the TDI liquid release from the rail car stopped once the residual nitrogen pressure in the car reached atmospheric pressure.  A third party environmental response contractor was contacted within an hour of this release to assist with the necessary clean up efforts, which were completed on the late afternoon of August 27, 2013.

As a result of this incident, the following corrective actions were implemented by Stolthaven Houston Inc. after review by the terminal's Management Steering Committee:  (1) the TDI incident was discussed in detail at a mandatory meeting conducted at Rail Rack R-2 for all facility Operations, Waste Water, and Maintenance Department personnel, (2) Standard Operating Procedures related to rail car switching were formally updated on September 20, 2013, and (3) operator training related to the revised rail car switching and blue flag procedures was conducted during Operations Departmental meetings held according to shift in September of 2013.  

Note that this incident did not result in any on-site deaths or injuries.  Similarly, there have been no accidental releases from any RMP covered processes in the past five years which resulted in known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

All incidents at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal are formally investigated as part of our facility's ISO Quality Management System (QMS) to identify and correct the root cause(s) of the events, and to implement appropriate corrective actions for continuous process improvement.


§ 68.155(e):  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protec

o D-Manifold, installing a dehydrator on the tank's vacuum breaker to help prevent moisture from entering the vapor space should there be a loss of plant nitrogen, and installing a carbon adsorption canister on the Storage Tank D-15-19 vapor line prior to the TDI vapors entering the terminal's common Tank Farm Vent Flare vapor header.  

ISOPENTANE INTERMODAL TRANSFERS

Isopentane is periodically transloaded directly between rail tank cars spotted at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's Rail Rack R-2 into ISO tank containers at Truck Rack T-6 with no intermediate product storage in any of the terminal's chemical storage tanks.  Vapors generated during these intermittent Isopentane transfer operations are directed to the terminal's Tank Farm Vent Flare for pollution control.  

VINYL ACETATE MONOMER STORAGE AND TRANSFERS

Storage Tank P-50-5 is an existing internal floating roof (IFR) tank at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal with a maximum working capacity of approximately 50,142-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 16,400,000-pounds.  Tank P-50-5, which represents the facility's worst-case release scenario, was placed into VAM service for the first time on February 25, 2010.  VAM is received into this tank via barge delivery using a dedicated marine dock line.  Product is stored and then shipped outbound according to customer requirements via marine parcel tankers that load at Stolthaven Houston's existing Ship Dock 2/3.  VAM may also be transferred periodically directly from barges to rail tank cars with no intermediate product storage, and VAM slops can also be received from marine vessels berthed at Stolthaven Houston.  

As a result of the 2010 VAM storage project for Tank P-50-5, piping modifications were completed in various facility manifolds and at Tank P-50-5 to eliminate the use of hoses in VAM service to the greatest extent possible within the terminal.  A VAM filter-pot was also installed adjacent to the sto

rage tank.  Stolthaven Houston's permanent, stationary fire-water protection systems in the immediate area of Tank P-50-5 were also upgraded to provide additional cooling water as-needed in the event of an emergency incident involving any of the the facility's flammable or combustible liquid storage tanks in close proximity.  Existing portable water delivery systems also remain available should they be needed in the event of an emergency.

Employee training related to the specifics of VAM storage and transfer at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal was first conducted in December of 2008 and then again in April of 2009 in preparation of receiving this RMP regulated substance into the facility's A-Tank Farm in 2009.  Although current facility employees have been trained and are experienced in the procedures necessary to safely handle VAM, additional safety training related specifically to VAM storage in P-Tank Farm was conducted in December of 2009.  Specific topics covered during this employee review of safe VAM handling procedures included, but were not limited to, the following information:  product transfer modes and affected facility equipment, VAM technical and physical properties, inhibitor specifications and periodic verification, nitrogen blanketing to maintain low oxygen levels, special product hazards and warnings, required personal protective equipment (PPE), and environmental/regulatory considerations.  VAM has been successfully handled at Stolthaven Houston Inc. since April of 2009 without significant incident.  

   
§ 68.155(c):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs, including:

- Process Safety Information (PSI)

- Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

- ISO 9001: 2000 Certified Quality Management System (QMS)

- Employe
